Herein, a series of nitrogen-containing polymer nanosheets bearing Cu2+ and VO2+ (Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA) were designed and displayed superior catalytic performance in the selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to FDCA. The catalyst was characterized by FT-IR, SEM, XPS, TG, UV–Vis DRS, PL, and ICP-AES analysis techniques. The effects of various reaction parameters, including the tert-butyl hydroperoxide dosage, temperature, and solvents on the HMF oxidation were systematically investigated, and the results were discussed in details. The Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst achieved 100% conversion of HMF with 98.6% selectivity toward FDCA without the requirement for any basic additives under mild conditions (90 °C, 10 h), as well as has a good reusability. Coupling of the active sites of Cu2+ and VO2+ provide a synergistic effect for FDCA production. This study may provide a novel method for the development of efficient non-precious metal catalyst without addition of alkali additives, benefiting the valorization of furan-based compounds into high-valued chemicals in industrial processes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Selective oxidation 5-hydroxymethylfurfural 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid Heterogeneous catalyst Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Nowadays, with the ever-increasing consumptions of non-renewable fossil energy such as crude oil and coal has brought serious energy crisis to human society, thereby rendering the discovery and development of sustainable energy and materials important tasks [1–3]. Biomass as the only renewable organic carbon resources that can be further employed to derive a lot of important oxygenated organic compounds, which can fully or partially replace the traditional fossil-based chemicals [4–6]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), is widely considered one of the most promising biomass-derived platform molecules [7–9], which can undergo various types of reactions, such as oxidation [10–12], photocatalytic oxidation [13–15], electrooxidation [16], hydrogenation [17], etherification [18], rearrangements [19], and polymerization [20]. As such, the oxidation of HMF to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) as a representative and important process for the comprehensive utilization of biomass resources, which has recently obtained wide attention [21]. In addition, FDCA is a renewable monomers that can be applied for the production of bio-based polymers, since two carboxylic groups are required for the syntheses of polyesters [22]. Among all polyesters, polyethylene furanoate (PEF) prepared by the polymerization of FDCA with ethylene glycol is widely applied in bottle packaging, clothing and fibers, and other industries [23]. Compared with the terephthalic acid-based polyethylene terephthalate (PET), PEF possesses a superior gas barrier and mechanical strength as well as a higher thermal stability. HMF need undergo multi-step successive oxidations to obtain FDCA, and achieving a high selectivity of FDCA from HMF is hence still a great challenge. Because the catalytic oxidation process often give three typical intermediate products, including 2,5-furan-dicarbaldehyde (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-furan-2-carboxylic acid (HFCA) and 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA). To date, intensive efforts have been devoted to study the catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA over various noble metal catalysts. Initially, Besson et al. developed a Pt/C catalyst for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA in a moderately basic aqueous solution, giving a FDCA yield of 69% [24]. More recently, Yu et al. proved that the superior performance of Pt/PVP-ACS-800 catalysts with a large surface area gave 99% HMF conversion with a >99% FDCA yield over 5 h at 110 °C [25]. In addition, Ma et al. prepared Au/CeO2-rods for the catalytic conversion of HMF, and a TOF value of 6.3 min−1 was obtained due to high oxygen vacancies and a synergistic effect existed among the interfacial Lewis acidic sites, homogenous base, and the neighboring Au particles [26]. Furthermore, Wang et al. prepared an Au-Pd/MPIL by varying the hydrophobic or hydrophilic properties of the cross-linkers for the production of FDCA using HMF as substrate, giving close to complete conversion and a 99% FDCA yield at 90 °C [27]. Moreover, Gui et al. introduced zinc hydroxycarbonate (ZOC) functional materials into a Au-Pd bimetallic for the selective oxidation of HMF, which resulted in an excellent activity at 80 °C and 3 bar O2 [28]. It was worthy noted that the above-mentioned noble metal catalysts exhibit encouraging results for the oxidation of HMF into FDCA, however, low availability and the high cost of precious metals hinder their actual applications. Recently, some non-noble metal catalysts, such as ionic liquids-heteropoly acids [29], MnFe2O4 [30], β-MnO2/NaHCO3 [31], 10M@xNb@MNP [32], and Cu/NG [33] have been developed. However, these catalytic systems required high reaction pressures and the use of aqueous alkaline solutions, which often associated with serious environmental concerns. Under such situation, heterogeneous catalyst with excellent activity for selective convert HMF into FDCA is highly desirable. It should be worthy noted that metal-organic coordination compounds have been widely applied as heterogeneous catalysts because of their large specific surface areas and high porosities [34]. Pourkhosravani et al. reported that UiO-66-SI/VO(acac) and UiO-66-N/VO(acac)2 employed as catalysts for the epoxidation of geraniol, in which the catalytic activities was due to the coordination between V and the MOF [35]. More importantly, the catalytic performance of coordination compounds can be rationally tuned owing to a variety of metal ions and organic ligand structures. More recently, our research groups have prepared and employed porous organic polymer (PDVTA) as a catalyst support [36–38], which exhibit high surface area and good thermal stability. Especially, PDVTA containing surface bound amine groups could efficiently coordination desirable metal ions, which can be employed for the specific catalytic processes. Here, a advanced catalyst based on the immobilization of Cu2+ and VO2+ on a nitrogen-containing polymer (Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA) was successfully prepared, exhibiting high catalytic oxidation activity and selectivity of HMF to FDCA, even at a low temperature and in the absence of base additive. In addition, the reusability of the catalyst was examined over a number of cycles, and a possible reaction mechanism over the Cu2+ -VO2+/PDVTA catalyst was further proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals HMF (≥98.0%) were obtained from Shanghai D&B Biological Science and Technology Co., Ltd. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (≥99.5%), tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, ≥65.0%), tert-butanol (TBA, ≥98.0%) and dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO, ≥99.5%) were acquired from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN, ≥98.0%) was procured from Jiangsu Qiangsheng Functional Chemical Co., Ltd. VOSO4 (≥98.0%) was purchased from Wuhan Boxing Chemical Co., Ltd. Divinylbenzene (≥80.0%) and triallylamine (≥97.0%) were acquired from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Based on a previous report [36,39], preparation of the PDVTA materials is illustrated in Scheme 1 . In a typical procedure, 12.0 mmol of divinylbenzene and 3.0 mmol of triallylamine were stirred in 30 mL of acetone in a 100 mL of flask for 15 min. The flask was protected with N2 atmosphere, and then 0.3 mmol of AIBN was immersed to the mixture. After stirring for 12 h, the obtained solution was transferred to an autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. Finally, the white powder was washed thoroughly with acetone and dried at 80 °C and was denoted as PDVTA. Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst was synthesized by an impregnation method. In a typical preparation, 2.0 mmol of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 2.5 mmol of VOSO4 were dissolved in an alcoholic solution (20 mL) containing 0.3 g of PDVTA at 50 °C and stirred for 3 h. Then, the pale blue mixture was centrifuged and washed with ethanol. Finally, the mixture was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h and denoted as 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA, where “0.8″ is the molar ratio of copper cations (Cu2+) to vanadyl cations (VO2+). Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalysts with different metal contents were synthesized according to the similar steps through variation in the number of moles of Cu2+ employed to give Cu2+/PDVTA, VO2+/PDVTA, 0.4 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA, and 1.2 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA. 2.3 Catalyst characterization FT-IR spectroscopy was performed on a Nicolet 370 infrared spectrophotometer in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 using the KBr pellet technique. The surface morphologies of Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA were inspected by SEM using a Quanta600F instrument and an X-ray energy spectrometer (EDX, IE350). XPS was preformed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+ spectrometer and the XPS Peak 4.1 software was utilized to fitting curves using the Shirley-type background subtraction. TG-DTG analyses were carried out on a Netzsch model STA 409 PC instrument heating from room temperature to 700 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C/min. UV–Vis DRS of the samples were conducted and collected on a Varian-Cary 5000 UV/Vis spectrophotometer. The fluorescence emission spectra were tested on a Hitachi Limited F-4500 spectrometer with a slit width of 5 nm. The metal contents in the samples were analyzed by ICP-AES using an iCAP 7200 Duo spectrometer. 2.4 HMF oxidation procedure Typically, 0.1 mmol of HMF, 1 mL of DMSO, 3 mL of TBA, 20 mg of 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA and 4 mmol of TBHP were added into flask, and the reaction was performed at 80 °C for 10 h under an air atmosphere. After reaction, the catalyst was filtered and the products were further analyzed by Agilent 1100 series of HPLC. The HMF conversion, FDCA selectivity and FDCA yield were calculated based on the following equations: HMF conversion = ( moles of converted HMF / moles of starting HMF ) × 100 % FDCA selectivity = ( moles of FDCA / moles of converted HMF ) × 100 % FDCA yield = moles of FDCA / moles of starting HMF × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA characterization FT-IR spectroscopy was performed to analyze the chemical structures of PDVTA, Cu2+/PDVTA, VO2+/PDVTA, and Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA, and the corresponding spectra are shown in Fig.1 . PDVTA have abundant functional groups, as confirmed by the visualization of absorption peaks at 3083, 2922, 2848, 1601, 1509, 1384, 794, and 710 cm−1 [36]. 1384 cm−1 peak corresponds to a C–N stretching vibration, suggesting that the N atoms were successfully introduced into the PDVTA [40]. The characteristic peak at 443 cm–1 in the fingerprint region was attributed to the Cu–N bond [41], indicating that the nitrogen atoms on the surface of PDVTA coordinate with Cu2+. In contrast, for the VO2+/PDVTA catalyst, the characteristic peak at around 3419 cm–1 was ascribed to the V-O-H stretching vibration, which is consistent with a previous literature [42]. The bands observed at 1176, 639, and 615 cm–1 in the FT-IR were assigned to V=O and V-O stretching vibrations, respectively [43–44]. Besides, the same characteristic peaks as those observed for the Cu2+/PDVTA and VO2+/PDVTA catalysts were also found in the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst. The FT-IR results indicate that Cu2+ and VO2+ were successfully anchored on the PDVTA surface. The SEM images of PDVTA and Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA displayed in Fig.2 clearly shows a relatively regular structure. A slight polymerization of the nanosheets was observed for the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst, indicating that Cu2+, VO2+, and PDVTA exist in the form of multiple coordination positions. From a morphological point of view, the catalyst is not affected by the introduction of metal ions. As indicated in Fig. 3 , the distribution of C, O, N, Cu, and V elements in the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst was probed. It was found that all elements were uniformly dispersed throughout the prepared PDVTA. Moreover, it is easily noted that Cu and V coordinate successfully with N without any partial agglomeration. Moreover, the element contents of C, N, V, O, and Cu were determined to be 77.18, 3.64, 0.06, 17.54, and 1.58%, respectively. In addition, the molar ratio of Cu to V was therefore determined to be approximately 25:1, which is in good agreement with the ICP results. XPS analysis of the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst further proved the chemical composition and provided additional information regarding the surface states of Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA. As shown in Fig. 4a , most of peaks were observed at 284.7, 399.8, 519.3, 532.7, and 936.1 eV for the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst, corresponding to the C, N, V, O, and Cu elements, respectively [45]. In the C1s region (Fig. 4b) after curve fitting, three different characteristic peaks could be obtained from the regional energy spectrum of C1s. The binding energies of the corresponding peak positions were 287.2, 285.6, and 284.5 eV, and these belong to the C-N, sp3-hybrid C-C, and sp2 C=C bonds, respectively [46–47]. The sp2 and sp3 hybridization of the carbon species mainly originated from the carrier PDVTA in the catalyst, according well with the structure of Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA. the peaks of high resolution N 1 s can be fitted into two sub-peaks at around 402.3 and 399.8 eV (Fig. 4c), which are typical for the graphitic N and quaternary N, respectively [48]. The rich nitrogen elements provided the possibility for the coordination of PDVTA with Cu and V ions. Fig. 4d shows the O 1 s specta of the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst. Four peaks mainly located at 534.3, 533.8, 532.7 and 531.5 eV, which can be indexed to the molecular water, adsorbed oxygen, V-O bonds, and surface lattice oxygen [49–50]. As shown in Fig. 4e, the Cu 2p peaks located at 936.1 and 957.2 eV belongs to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively. Additionally, two peaks observed at 944.7 and 963.3 eV suggest the existence of Cu2+ in the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst [51]. As shown in Cu Auger LMM spectra (Fig. 4f), the binding energy located at 916.6 eV corresponds to the reduced Cu+ species [52]. These results demonstrate Cu existed in the form of Cu2+ and Cu+ species in the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst [48]. The TGA results for the PDVTA, Cu2+/PDVTA, VO2+/PDVTA, and Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA samples were compared, as shown in Fig. 5 . As for PDVTA, a main weight loss was observed between 300 and 400 °C, which can be ascribed to the cleavage of C-C and C-N bond, suggesting that the PDVTA has a good thermal stability [36]. In addition, the Cu2+/PDVTA, VO2+/PDVTA, and Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalysts were found to exhibit a weight loss stages at 270–370 °C in the TG-DTG curves. These weight losses were ascribed to the collapse of the PDVTA framework due to the introduction of Cu2+ and VO2+ species, and therefore influenced the stability of the PDVTA. The results implied the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalysts could keep thermal stability when the temperature below 270 °C. To understand the variation of the optical bandgap upon changing the substitution of metal atoms in the PDVTA, the UV–vis DRS spectra of Cu2+/PDVTA, VO2+/PDVTA, and Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA were obtained with PDVTA as a reference (Fig. 6 ). The absorption edge at 264 nm shown in the figure was ascribed to the π–π * transition of the benzene ring in the PDVTA sample [53]. Cu2+/PDVTA, Cu2+/PDVTA, and Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA s generally exhibit weak absorption in the UV light to visible light region. In addition, the UV–vis DRS spectra of the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalysts containing different copper-vanadium mole ratios are displayed in Fig. S1, where the different degrees of blue shift indicate that part of the introduced Cu2+ and Cu+ species are incorporated into the PDVTA framework, consistent with the FT-IR and XPS results [53]. The majority of metal ions possess typical fluorescence emission spectrum characteristics under the excitation of different wavelengths. Thus, in order to investigate the underlying interactions between PDVTA and VO2+ and Cu2+, the PL emission spectra of the Cu2+/PDVTA, VO2+/PDVTA, and Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA samples were thus recorded (Fig. 7 ). For the Cu2+/PDVTA catalyst, strong emission and excitation wavelengths were detected at approximately 350 and 423 nm, respectively [54]. Similarly, the VO2+/PDVTA catalyst exhibited emission wavelengths and excitation wavelengths of 532 and 585 nm, respectively [55]. The PL emission spectra of the catalysts with different copper-vanadium ratios are shown in Fig. S2. These findings indicate that Cu2+ and VO2+ were successfully embedded in the PDVTA frame during impregnation. 3.2 Catalyst screening Table 1 summarized the experimental results of HMF oxidation over various catalysts. Obviously, it did not generate the desired FDCA in the absence of catalyst. Meanwhile, it was found that PDVTA exhibit a lower activity with 50.9% of HMF conversion. However, the intermediate HFCA was detected, and its selectivity could reach 38.2%. It is possible that the alkaline lone pairs of the N atoms on the PDVTA can preferentially attack the aldehyde group of HMF, thereby forming HFCA. When the Cu2+/PDVTA catalyst was employed, the conversion of HMF increased to 100%, and the FDCA selectivity increased to 60.7%. This can be explained by the fact that Cu2+ is coordinated with PDVTA, facilitating the oxidation process. Another control experiment was also conducted over VO2+/PDVTA catalyst, and the HMF conversion reached 99.7 with 78.3% FDCA selectivity. Interestingly, the satisfying catalytic results of were observed over Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalysts. These observations indicate that a remarkable synergistic effect existed between the Cu2+ and VO2+ activity sites in the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalysts on enhancing oxidation process. From these results, it was apparent that when the Cu/V ratio was increased from 0.4 to 0.8, the selectivity towards FDCA increased from 89.4 to 93.1%. The 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA and 1.2 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalysts, however, showed similar catalytic activities, likely due to the fact that the Cu and V species in 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA are fully coordinated with the nitrogen atoms. The mole ratio of Cu2+ to V2+ determined by ICP experiments as outlined in Table S1. Indeed, the ICP experiments also confirm that the 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA and 1.2 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalysts possess the similar Cu/V ratios. Based on this, 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA was selected in this study for subsequent experiments. Reaction conditions: HMF, 0.1 mmol; catalyst, 20 mg; DMSO, 1 mL; TBA, 3 mL; TBHP, 6 mmol; 5 h, 90 °C. 3.3 Effect of TBHP loading on the oxidation of HMF to FDCA The conversion of HMF remained >98% in all cases, and it seems that HMF conversion essentially unaffected by the amount of TBHP (Fig.8 ). Notably, the selectivity toward FDCA rapidly increased from 52.6 to 98.6% upon increasing the amount of TBHP from 1 to 6 mmol. It is highly possible that the higher concentration of O2 molecules generated in solution in the presence higher TBHP loadings [30], facilitating oxidation reaction with highly selectivity. The above findings suggest that the selectivity of FDCA is positively correlated to the amount of TBHP present in the reaction system. 3.4 Effect of solvent composition on the oxidation of HMF to FDCA As shown in Fig. 9 , a 35.5% conversion of HMF was obtained when ethanol/ DMSO mixture solvent were employed as the mixed solvent, which may be due to the fact that low solubility of HMF in a low-polarity solvent. Obviously, the HMF conversion increased to almost 100% in higher polarities solvents. However, the selectivity toward FDCA was only 10.6% in a DMSO/water mixture solvent. A similar result was obtained in pure DMSO, and very few furan products were obtained due to the insolubility of FDCA; the main by-products of the reaction were humic amines originating from HMF polymerization [29]. When MeCN was mixed with DMSO as an aprotic solvent, a 91.6% FDCA selectivity was obtained. In the case of sole TBA solvent, it was observed that the catalyst showed encourage activity for HMF conversion, whereas the selectivity of FDCA was 84.7%. On the one hand, TBA can efficiently inhibit the TBHP decomposition during the reaction, thereby ensuring that TBHP can continue to provide · OH radicals [12]. On the other hand, the reaction temperature cannot exceed the boiling point of TBA, and the activity energy required for the reaction is still insufficient. Thus, DMSO was mixed with TBA using the azeotropic principle to ameliorate the catalytic ability of Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA. Among the various organic reaction systems examined, it is concluded that in the DMSO/TBA mixed solvent obtain the highest FDCA selectivity (98.6%). 3.5 Effect of reaction temperature on the oxidation of HMF to FDCA As indicated in Fig. 10 , the selectivity of FDCA was positively correlated with the reaction temperature ranging from 60 °C to 90 °C. A poor catalytic activity and no target product were obtained when the reaction conducted at low temperature (60 °C). The products, FFCA, DFF, and HFCA, accounts a high proportion in the oxidation products, indicating that the oxidation of HMF was not complete. It was found that the highest reactivity was achieved at 90 °C, giving 100% HMF conversion and 98.6% FDCA selectivity. This observation suggests that the higher reaction temperature can gradually promote the intermediates into FDCA, thus improving the FDCA selectivity. 3.6 Effect of reaction time on the oxidation of HMF to FDCA Fig. 11 shows a rapidly increase trend for HMF conversion at the initial stage of the reaction, reaching 97.6% HMF conversion after 2 h. However, the selectivity of FDCA was just 31.3%, with the main products being HFCA (8.4%), DFF (11.8%), and FFCA (48.5%), indicating that HMF was indirectly transformed into FDCA during the oxidation process. As the reaction time was prolonged, intermediate products gradually transformed into FDCA, and the FDCA selectivity reached the maximum value (98.6%) after 24 h. Initially, the selectivity toward DFF and HFCA were increased, reaching a maximum DFF selectivity and HFCA selectivity of 27.6% and 24.9% after 0.5 h, respectively, but then decreased rapidly. It was observed that the maximum FFCA selectivity (i.e., 56.9%) was obtained after 1 h. These results suggest that the distribution of reaction products is strongly affected by the reaction time. This also means that the oxidation pathways of HMF were involved HMF→DFF→FFCA→FDCA and HMF→HFCA→FFCA→FDCA, which may be attributed to the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst has good oxidation ability for both the -OH and -CHO side-chains of HMF. 3.7 Catalyst recyclability Reusability testing was further performed to evaluate the catalytic stability of the Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst. After reaction, 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst was easily separated by high-speed centrifugation and then dried in an oven at 100 °C. The mass loss of catalyst ranged around from 0 to 4 mg. According to the determined catalyst mass losses, the proportions of other reagents were reduced in the subsequent reaction to ensure that the ratio of catalyst active sites to HMF was the same in all reactions. As can be seen in Fig.S3, after four cycles, the conversion of HMF did not change much with the selectivity of FDCA decreased slightly (87.6 to 76.4%). It was noted that the selectivity toward FFCA increased gradually from 11.8 to 22.7%, indicating that the catalytic performance of the catalyst slowly decreased due to the slight deactivation. To study the deactivation of the catalyst in detail, a hot filtration test was further performed. For this purpose, a group of comparative experiments was carried out, whereby the catalyst was either not separated (blank control) or separated from the reaction system. Fig.S4 shows the FDCA yield increased rapidly with prolonging the reaction time. After removal of catalyst, the FDCA yield increased slightly from 31.8 to 36.3% in 2 h, however, once more upon re-addition of the 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst the FDCA yield increased rapidly. These results clearly demonstrate that a small quantity of the active ingredient of the 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst may be lost during the reaction process. Based on the ICP-AES results (Table S1), the negligible V contents of the 0.8 Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst had been leached from the catalyst after four runs, which may be attributed to the slight decrease in catalytic activity, which is also supported by the recycling experiment results. 3.8 Possible reaction mechanism According to the above results and the reported literature [56–57], a possible mechanism for HMF oxidation to FDCA over Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA was proposed, as shown in Fig. 12 . HMF is firstly adsorbed on Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA surface and further oxidized via the redox cycle of V5+/V4+ of vanadium species and Cu2+/Cu+, forming the desired FDCA. TBHP provides an oxygen source for the reaction, in which cleavage of the O-O bond results in decomposition to a tert-butoxy radical (tBuO·) and a hydroxyl radical (HO·) under heating [58]. At the same time, V4+ of vanadium species and Cu+ are rapidly oxidized, affording V5+ of vanadium species and Cu2+, respectively. Both V5+ of vanadium species and Cu2+ ions with strong oxidation ability co-promote the oxidation of HMF, achieving highly selectivity for FDCA in the current work. 4 Conclusion In this work, Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalysts with varied Cu/V ratios was designed and applied to catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. Detailed characterization of the catalyst was performed to reveal that Cu2+ and VO2+ were successfully immobilized on the PDVTA framework, and variation in the metal molar ratio was found to be closely associated with the catalytic performance. The results illustrate that Cu2+ and VO2+ synergistically promoted the oxidation of HMF into FDCA. The Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst exhibited a robust activity and stability with excellent FDCA selectivity in recycling experiments. Hopefully, this work may offer a guideline for the development of non-precious metals that employ mild conditions and alkali-free additives in production of furan-based compounds and in catalytic bio-based conversion process. coredata.dc:description: 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), which is recognized as a valuable alternative to petroleum-derived terephthalic acid and produce more bio-based polymers, has attracted considerable attention in recent years. Herein, a series of nitrogen-containing polymer nanosheets bearing Cu2+ and VO2+ (Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA) were designed and displayed superior catalytic performance in the selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to FDCA. The catalyst was characterized by FT-IR, SEM, XPS, TG, UV–Vis DRS, PL, and ICP-AES analysis techniques. The effects of various reaction parameters, including the tert-butyl hydroperoxide dosage, temperature, and solvents on the HMF oxidation were systematically investigated, and the results were discussed in details. The Cu2+-VO2+/PDVTA catalyst achieved 100% conversion of HMF with 98.6% selectivity toward FDCA without the requirement for any basic additives under mild conditions (90 °C, 10 h), as well as has a good reusability. Coupling of the active sites of Cu2+ and VO2+ provide a synergistic effect for FDCA production. This study may provide a novel method for the development of efficient non-precious metal catalyst without addition of alkali additives, benefiting the valorization of furan-based compounds into high-valued chemicals in industrial processes.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient targeted acquisition 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid derived from 5-hydroxymethylfurfural over novel copper and vanadium oxide-functionalized catalysts
